Novel bi-SO3H-functionalized ionic liquids based on piperazinium: Highly efficient and recyclable catalysts for the synthesis of β-acetamido ketones Yuanyuan Wang Junlong Zhou Kun Liu Liyi Dai ⁎ Department of Chemistry, East China Normal University, Dongchuan Road 500, 20021 Shanghai, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 21 62233037; fax: +86 21 62602447. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Several bi-SO3H-functionalized ionic liquids (BSFILs) were developed. ► BSFILs exhibited higher activities compared to single-SO3H-functionalized ILs. ► IL with shorter hydrogen bond had stronger acidity and higher catalytic activity. ► Low cost, high yields, short reaction times were the key features of this method. A series of novel bi-SO3H-functionalized ionic liquids were synthesized and acted as catalysts for the synthesis of β-acetamido ketones. Compared with traditional single-SO3H-functionalized ionic liquids, less amount of catalysts, higher yields and shorter reaction time are the key features of this methodology. Hammett function values and the minimum-energy geometries of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs were calculated and the results revealed that the acidities and catalytic activities of ILs in synthesis of β-acetamido ketones were influenced by their structures. The IL [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 with the shortest HO bond distance had the strongest acidity and the highest catalytic activity. Keywords Ionic liquids Bi-SO3H-functionalized Acidity characterization Hammett function Catalytic activity β-Acetamido ketones 1 Introduction One of the main principles of green chemistry is to develop cost-effective and environmentally benign catalytic systems which have become one of the main themes of contemporary synthetic chemistry. Ionic liquids (ILs) have been considered as eco-friendly alternatives to volatile organic media because of their negligible vapor pressure and nonflammable nature [1,2]. Although IL was initially introduced as an alternative green reaction medium, today it has marched far beyond showing its significant role in controlling the reaction as a catalyst. ILs are composed of distinct cations and anions that are capable of facilely tuning, whereby they can be designed for task-specific applications through smart choice of the respective cation and/or anion. The introduction of specific functionality has led to the identification of functionalized ILs (FILs, or taskspecific ILs, TSILs) [3–5]. Among different kinds of FILs, SO3H-functionalized ILs have been intensively studied [6–8]. They were used as solvent-catalysts for several organic reactions such as esterifications, Aldol condensation, Pinacole reaction, Biginelli reaction and so on. The use of such TSILs as catalysts is an area of current investigations and as aforementioned, these TSILs may further expand the application of ILs in chemistry. One of significant challenges in the way of development and commercialization of TSILs is high cost [9]. In continuation of our studies on the preparation and application of SO3H-functionalized ILs [10–12], we herein reported the synthesis of novel bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs available from cheaper raw materials and simpler preparation procedure (Scheme 1 ). Multicomponent reactions (MCRs) have drawn great interest in modern organic synthesis and medicinal chemistry because of their one-pot processes about bringing together three or more components, high atom economy and high selectivity [13–15]. β-Acetamido ketone derivatives are useful building blocks for a number of biologically and pharmaceutically valuable compounds [16–18]. Recently, it is reported that β-acetamido ketones can act as aglucosidase inhibitors [19]. β-Acetamido ketones have been synthesized through MCRs using Zr(HSO4)4 [20], Mg(HSO4)2 [20], Cu(OTf)2 [21], H3PW12O40 [22], FeCl3·6H2O [23], SnCl2·2H2O [24], silica-supported sulfuric acid [25], etc. as catalysts. Although these methods are quite useful, they have limitations, such as low yields, tedious work-up procedures and harsh reaction conditions. Zare et al. [26] and Heravi et al. [27] also reported the synthesis of β-acetamido ketones catalyzed by IL [Et3N-SO3H]Cl and [HO3S(CH2)4MIM][HSO4]. Their methods avoided using toxic catalysts, however, they were still met with the problems of using large amount of ILs and experiencing long reaction time. We have reported the effective catalytical results of single SO3H-functionalized ILs to the organic reactions [10–12], so we predicted that our bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs could also catalyze the synthesis of β-acetamido ketones efficiently (Scheme 2 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and instruments All chemicals were analytical grade and used as received. The melting points were determined on Sanyo Gallenkamp MPD350 apparatus. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Brucker DRX-500 spectrometer. FT-IR measurements were performed using KBr disc on a NEXUS 670 FT-IR infrared spectrometer (Nicolet). 2.2 Synthesis and characterization of ILs 1,4-Bis(3-sulfopropyl) piperazinium ((PS) 2 pi): Piperazine (0.86g, 0.01mol) and distilled water (10mL) were placed in a three necked flask with a stirrer. Then 1,3-propane sultone (3.05g, 0.025mol) was added slowly within 5min with reflux. After that, the reaction mixture was stirred for 5min and then cooled to room temperature. The product was recrystallized out at pH 4 and 0°C following addition of NaOH, then washed with distilled water for three times and dried at 100°C for 3h. The final product (PS)2pi was white powder. 1,4-Bis(4-sulfobutyl) piperazinium ((BS) 2 pi): Piperazine (0.86g, 0.01mol) and distilled water (10mL) were placed in a three necked flask with a stirrer. Then 1,4-butane sultone (3.40g, 0.025mol) was added slowly within 5min with reflux. After that, the reaction mixture was stirred for 30min and then cooled to room temperature. The product was recrystallized out from NaOH of pH 4 at 0°C, then washed with distilled water three times and dried at 100°C for 3h. The final product (BS)2pi was white powder. 1,4-Bis(3-sulfopropyl) piperazinium bis(hydrogen sulfate) ([(PS) 2 pi][HSO 4 ] 2 ), 1,4-bis(3-sulfopropyl) piperazinium bis(hydrogen sulfate) ([(PS) 2 pi][H 2 PO 4 ] 2 ), 1,4-bis(3-sulfopropyl) piperazinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonate) ([(PS) 2 pi][OTf] 2 ): Under strong stirring, (PS)2pi (0.01mol) was dissolved into water (10mL). 0.02M sulfuric acid, phosphoric acid or trifluoromethanesulfonic acid was dropped slowly into it at room temperature. After the dropping, the solution was heated up to 90°C slowly and stirred for 2h, then water was removed under vacuum at 70°C for 3h. The final products [(PS)2pi][HSO4]2, [(PS)2pi][H2PO4]2 and [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 were white powders. 1,4-Bis(4-sulfobutyl) piperazinium bis(hydrogen sulfate) ([(BS) 2 pi][HSO 4 ] 2 ), 1,4-bis(4-sulfobutyl) piperazinium bis(hydrogen sulfate) ([(BS) 2 pi][H 2 PO 4 ] 2 ), 1,4-bis(4-sulfobutyl) piperazinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonate) ([(BS) 2 pi][OTf] 2 ): Under strong vigorous stirring, (BS)2pi (0.01mol) was dissolved into water (10mL). 0.02mol sulfuric acid, phosphoric acid or trifluoromethanesulfonic acid was dropped slowly into it at room temperature. After the dropping, the solution was slowly heated up to 90°C and stirred for 2h, then the water was removed under vacuum at 70°C for 3h. The final products [(BS)2pi][HSO4]2, [(BS)2pi][H2PO4]2 and [(BS)2pi][OTf]2 were white powders. IR (KBr, ν/cm−1): 3427, 3128, 2689, 1633, 1458, 1236, 1163, 1052, 1021, 596, 540. 1H NMR (500MHz, D2O) δ: 1.75 (m, 4H, CH2CH 2CH2), 1.84 (m, 4H, NCH2CH 2), 2.87 (t, 4H, CH 2SO3H), 3.25 (t, 4H, NCH 2CH2), 3.85 (t, 8H, pi). [(BS) 2 pi][H 2 PO 4 ] 2 : M.p. (°C): 225–227. IR (KBr, ν/cm−1): 3421, 3027, 2951, 2689, 2486, 1643, 1473, 1236, 1166, 1027, 594, 553. 1H NMR (500MHz, D2O) δ: 1.86 (m, 4H, CH2CH 2CH2), 1.95 (m, 4H, NCH2CH 2), 2.99 (t, 4H, CH 2SO3H), 3.37 (t, 4H, NCH 2CH2), 3.73 (t, 8H, pi). [(BS) 2 pi][OTf] 2 : M.p. (°C): 106–107. IR (KBr, ν/cm−1): 3400, 3003, 2698, 2501, 1631, 1477, 1384, 1295, 1169, 1033, 633, 584, 532. 1H NMR (500MHz, D2O) δ: 1.78 (m, 4H, CH2CH 2CH2), 1.89 (m, 4H, NCH2CH 2), 2.92 (t, 4H, CH 2SO3H), 3.31 (t, 4H, NCH 2CH2), 3.88 (t, 8H, pi). 2.3 UV–vis acidity evaluation ILs were dissolved into distilled H2O and characterized by UV–vis spectra with an Agilent B453 spectrophotometer. 2.4 Computational methods The minimum-energy geometries of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs and isolated [(PS)2pi]+, [(BS)2pi]+ cations were determined by performing ab initio geometry optimizations at the RHF/6-31(d,p) level using the Gaussian 03 program. A vibrational analysis was performed to ensure the absence of negative frequencies and verify the existence of a true minimum. 2.5 General procedure for synthesis of β-acetamido ketones Aryl ketone (5mmol), aryl aldehyde (5mmol), acetyl chloride (1.5mL), acetonitrile (15mL), and IL (10mol%) were mixed and stirred at room temperature for 50–110min. After the reaction, the mixture was poured into ice-cold water and stirred thoroughly, then precipitated to get the desired β-acetamido ketones. The precipitated solid was isolated by filtration and washed with diethyl ether. The pure product was obtained by recrystallization from ethyl acetate–n-hexane. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Determination of H 0 values of ILs The measurement of the acidic scale of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs was conducted on an Agilent B453 UV-vis spectrophotometer with a basic indicator crystal violet [28]. With the increase of acidic scale of ILs, the absorbance of the unprotonated form of the basic indicator decreased, whereas the protonated form of the indicator could not be observed. It is because of its small molar absorptivity and its location. The [I]/[IH+] (I represents indicator) ratio could be determined from the measured absorbance differences after addition of ILs, the Hammett function (H 0), was calculated by using Eq. (1). This value could be considered as the relative acidity of the ILs (1) H 0 = p K ( I ) aq + log [ I ] [ IH + ] H 0 values of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs were calculated with the same concentration of crystal violet (5mg/L, pK a =0.8) and ILs (25mmol/L) in distilled water. For comparison, we also determined the H 0 values of single-SO3H-functionalized ILs based on pyridium. The maximal absorbance of the unprotonated form of the indicator was observed at 590nm. When an acidic IL was added, the absorbance of the unprotonated form of the indicator decreased. As is shown in Fig. 1 , the absorbance of the unprotonated form of the indicator on nine ILs decreased as follows: [PSpy][H2PO4]>[(BS)2pi][H2PO4]2 >[PSpy][HSO4]>[(PS)2pi][H2PO4]2 >[(PS)2pi][HSO4]2 >[PSpy][OTf]>[(BS)2pi][HSO4]2 >[(BS)2pi][OTf]2 >[(PS)2pi][OTf]2. The acidity order of these SO3H-functionalized ILs is with the following H 0 values (Table 1 ): [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 (−0.2616)>[(BS)2pi][OTf]2 (0.0240)>[(BS)2pi][HSO4]2 (0.1248)>[(PS)2pi][HSO4]2 (0.1925)>[PSpy][OTf] (0.2087)>[(PS)2pi][H2PO4]2 (0.2452)>[PSpy][HSO4] (0.5707)>[(BS)2pi][H2PO4]2 (0.9170)>[PSpy][H2PO4] (1.0958). The results indicated that the acidities of ILs became stronger with the increase of the number of SO3H-functionalized groups. The acidities of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs depended on the characteristics of both cations and anions. The ILs with [(PS)2pi]+ cations had stronger acidities than those with [(BS)2pi]+ cations. When the cations of the ILs were the same, the dependence of the acidity of the IL on anion was significant. The acidity of the bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs with [OTf]− was stronger than that of the ILs with [HSO4]− and [H2PO4]− anions (Table 1, entries 1–6). 3.2 The molecular geometries of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs The minimum-energy geometries of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs were determined by performing ab initio geometry optimizations at the RHF/6-31(d,p) level. The fully optimized geometries of these ILs were presented in Figs. 2 and 3 and Table 2 . It is obvious that a strong hydrogen bond network is presence in the bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs. Taking IL [(PS)2pi][HSO4]2 as an example, the anions were located on the side of the propyl sulfonic acid groups, and interact with the propyl alkyl sulfonic acid group and piperazinium ring in the form of C(N)H⋯O or OH⋯O type (hydrogen bonds). There were ten hydrogen bonds in IL [(PS)2pi][HSO4]2, which were shorter than the Van der Waals distance of 2.67Å [27]. These included the hydrogen bonds N14 H55⋯O43, N13 H56⋯O48, C1 H7⋯O51, C2 H5⋯O54 (bond distances are 1.541Å, 1.541Å, 2.251Å, 2.252Å) between the anion and piperazinium ring; the hydrogen bonds C25 H30⋯O43, C16 H21⋯O48 (bond distances are 2.552Å, 2.552Å) between the anion and alkyl sulfonic acid chain. Most importantly, the strongest interaction between the anion and the sulfonic acid proton was O39 H40⋯O45, O41 H42⋯O46 (bond distance is 1.736Å, 1.735Å). The other five bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs also exhibited similar strong interactions between the anions and the sulfonic acid groups. Those interactions could make the HO bond of the sulfonic acid groups to be lengthened with different levels compared with the one in the isolated cation. When the cations of the ILs were the same, the HO bond distance of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs decreased as follows: [Cation][H2PO4]2 >[Cation][HSO4]2 >[Cation][OTf]2. Taking ILs based on [(PS)2pi]+ cation as examples, the HO bond distance of the sulfonic acid group of these ILs decreased as follows: [(PS)2pi][H2PO4]2 (H50 O39 =1.343Å, H44 O43 =1.345Å)>[(PS)2pi][HSO4]2 (H40 O39 =1.011Å, H42 O41 =1.011Å)>[(PS)2pi][OTf]2 (H42 O41 =1.008Å, H40 O39 =1.009Å), which was reverse to their acidity sequence. When the anions of the ILs were the same, the HO bond distance of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs with ((PS)2pi)+ cations were shorter than that with ((BS)2pi)+ cations. Taking ILs with [H2PO4]− anion as examples, the HO bond distance of the sulfonic acid group of these ILs decreased as follows: [(PS)2pi][H2PO4]2 (H50 O39 =1.343Å, H44 O43 =1.345Å)<[(BS)2pi][H2PO4]2 (H48 O47 =1.463Å, H46 O45 =1.515Å), which was also reverse to their acidity sequence. The formation of hydrogen bond was a process of sharing lone electron pair of O or F atom with H atom. When the hydrogen bond was strong, the lone electron pair was shared in deep degree, and caused an increase in the electron density, and finally caused the decrease of H atom acidity. The results obtained from experiments and the minimum energy geometries of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs revealed that the acidities and catalytic activities of ILs were related to their structures. The bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs with shorter HO bond has stronger acidity and higher catalytic activity in the synthesis of β-acetamido ketones. 3.3 The comparative study on the catalytic activities of the different ILs A comparative study on the catalytic activities of the novel bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs with other ILs was carried out using the synthesis of N-(3-phenyl)-3-oxo-1-phenylpropyl)acetamide as a model reaction (Fig. 4 ). Zare et al. [26] and Heravi et al. [27] reported the application of IL [Et3N-SO3H]Cl and [HO3S(CH2)4MIM][HSO4] in the synthesis of β-acetamido ketones. However, those procedures encountered the problems of longer reaction time and larger usage of ILs. As is shown in Fig. 4, under the same reaction condition (r.t., 50min, 10mol% IL), the best yield of N-(3-phenyl)-3-oxo-1-phenylpropyl)acetamide was 92% with the presence of [(PS)2pi][OTf]2. When [Et3N-SO3H]Cl and [HO3S(CH2)4MIM][HSO4] were used as catalysts, the yields were 78% and 82%, respectively. It is very interesting that the sequence of catalytic activities of SO3H-functionalized ILs observed in the synthesis of N-(3-phenyl)-3-oxo-1-phenylpropyl)acetamide was in good agreement with the acidity order determined by the Hammett method. Therefore, [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 was chosen as the model catalyst for further investigation. 3.4 Synthesis of various β-acetamido ketones derivatives catalyzed by IL [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 To extend the preparative utility and generality of this MCR, a variety of aromatic aldehydes and ketones containing both electron-donating and withdrawing substituents were used to obtain the corresponding β-acetamido ketones derivatives with good yields under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 3 ). As is shown in Table 3, all kinds of aromatic aldehydes and ketones could react smoothly and obtained above 85% yields in shorter reaction time. 3.5 Reusability of IL [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 It is well-known that the stability and reusability of a catalyst system are the two key factors that identify whether it has potentially application in industry. In order to test the catalyst reusability, the reaction was carried out in the presence of [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 (10mol%) under the optimal reaction conditions to synthesize N-(3-phenyl)-3-oxo-1-phenylpropyl)acetamide. When the reaction finished, the mixture was poured into ice-cold water and stirred thoroughly, which resulted in precipitation of N-(3-phenyl)-3-oxo-1-phenylpropyl)acetamide. The catalyst was soluble in H2O and could be recovered and reused conveniently after heat treatment under vacuum at 70°C for 2h. The recovered rate of catalyst could reach as high as 95–98%. The results are shown in Fig. 5 , and indicated that the isolated yield of the product N-(3-phenyl)-3-oxo-1-phenylpropyl)acetamide was almost consistent after eight runs and [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 could be reused at least eight times. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a new group of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs were synthesized and showed high efficient catalytic activities for synthesis of β-acetamido ketones. Easier synthesis procedure, lower cost, higher yields, wider applicability and reusability are the key features of this methodology. The results obtained from the experiments and the minimum-energy geometries of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs revealed that the acidities and catalytic activities of ILs in synthesis of β-acetamido ketones were influence by their structures. The ILs with shorter HO bond distance had stronger acidity and higher catalytic activity. These conclusions will be helpful for detailed understanding of these bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs and will contribute to the design and synthesis of ILs in a “task specific” way. coredata.dc:description: A series of novel bi-SO3H-functionalized ionic liquids were synthesized and acted as catalysts for the synthesis of β-acetamido ketones. Compared with traditional single-SO3H-functionalized ionic liquids, less amount of catalysts, higher yields and shorter reaction time are the key features of this methodology. Hammett function values and the minimum-energy geometries of bi-SO3H-functionalized ILs were calculated and the results revealed that the acidities and catalytic activities of ILs in synthesis of β-acetamido ketones were influenced by their structures. The IL [(PS)2pi][OTf]2 with the shortest HO bond distance had the strongest acidity and the highest catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Novel bi-SO3H-functionalized ionic liquids based on piperazinium: Highly efficient and recyclable catalysts for the synthesis of β-acetamido ketones
